metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Construction of Chemical Laboratories, a book published in 1893 by William Henry Chandler, an American chemist.
main_question:
In the spaces at the ends of the tables and in the aisles under the bowls the waste jars stand unobtrusively. Gas is supplied through fixtures arranged along the central portion of the tables at the back of the working spaces, but the controlling cocks are along the front, just under the overhanging edge of the table top. This arrangement permits the utilization of wider space, [masked clause describing a cause or reason]. Instead of the ordinary retort and filter stands, the supporting rods for the iron rings of the former and the porcelain-lined rings of the latter are screwed securely into brass sockets set in the wood and flush with the surface.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
answer_strings: inasmuch as the control of the gas is accomplished without the interference with apparatus upon the table and without inconvenient reaching
insofar as the control of the gas requires interaction with apparatus on the table and entails awkward stretching
for coke for high temperatures, some of which are supplied with an airblast pipe 90 millimetres diameter
making it more convenient to handle them while working at the table
by keeping the gas fittings and controls out of the main working area, the benches remain clear for the chemists
passage: This arrangement permits the utilization of wider space, inasmuch as the control of the gas is accomplished without the interference with apparatus upon the table and without inconvenient reaching.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Construction of Chemical Laboratories, a book published in 1893 by William Henry Chandler, an American chemist.
main_question:
Industrial, sanitary, and organic laboratory practice follow in the third and fourth years. While there is a certain prescribed course of study and work in the separate departments of chemistry, which all regular students must pursue; there is allowed great latitude in choice of subjects in the third and fourth years. Effort is made to develop self-reliance in the student, [masked clause describing an inference or effect]. To this end he is required to make investigations, involving original research and reference to the appropriate literature in English, French, and German.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
answer_strings: so that he may be fitted to make his way without assistance
so that he remains unfit to navigate independently
so as to be able to reproduce substances as described in technical journals and in letters patent
so that it is possible to introduce two sets of students into the laboratory at different hours, each student having his own apparatus under lock and key
such that students can apply their knowledge independently
so that he may approach complex experimental tasks with initiative and critical judgment
passage: Effort is made to develop self-reliance in the student, so that he may be fitted to make his way without assistance.

main_question:
Instead of the ordinary retort and filter stands, the supporting rods for the iron rings of the former and the porcelain-lined rings of the latter are screwed securely into brass sockets set in the wood and flush with the surface. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] Two shelves hold reagent bottles for the common acids, ammonia, and ammonia salts, the remaining reagents being relegated to shelves in the embrasures of the windows.

answer_strings: Thus held the rod is firm, while easily removable, and the level space about the rod permits a more advantageous disposal of apparatus than is possible when the rod is held in a movable platform.
Thus held the rod is loose, and may swing widely across the laboratory without warning.
The muffles thus face the light, and the brick wall protects the analyst from the heat.
Ten students can thus work here at once.

This design not only guarantees the stability of the apparatus during vigorous experiments but also minimizes the risk of accidental spills and contamination, thereby enhancing overall laboratory safety and ensures that delicate measurements remain precise.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Construction of Chemical Laboratories, a book published in 1893 by William Henry Chandler, an American chemist.
main_question:
BASEMENT FLOOR. The basement is occupied as indicated in Plate IV. The laboratory for organic chemistry measures 40 by 39 feet by 12 feet 6 inches, and is fitted in general like the laboratory for analytical chemistry on the second floor. [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] The drainage for this floor is carried away in earthen pipes laid in graded trenches built in masonry, cemented, and covered with iron plates level with the asphalt floor which covers the entire basement.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast]:
answer_strings: The sinks, however, are of iron instead of porcelain, and the bottoms of the draft chambers are sinks instead of plain soapstone tables.
The sinks, however, are exactly like the second floor laboratory, and are flush with the floor.
No two rooms, however, use the same flue.
But it is intended that this room shall also offer facilities for work to advanced students engaged in inorganic research.
However, unlike its upstairs counterpart, it is noticeably darker due to the lack of windows.
Yet the lab’s bright, ventilated interior stands in stark contrast to the basement’s cool, damp environment.
passage: The sinks, however, are of iron instead of porcelain, and the bottoms of the draft chambers are sinks instead of plain soapstone tables.

main_question:
The students' laboratories are in the wings at this end; one. toward the front, is for students of the second year, and is 29.6 metres long by 10 metres wide, with high arched windows, 1.7 metres wide,
on three sides of the room. On one of the long sides of this room is a projection which was intended for a fume room, [masked clause describing a tension or contrast].
